question: Question_02
statement:
For each of the following subsets of $\mathbb R$ write its supremum and
infimum if they exist. If they do not exist write ``None``. You do not
need to prove your answers.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\left\{ x\in \mathbb R \text{ s.t. } -1 < x < 5 \right\},$
\item
  $\left\{ x\in \mathbb Q \text{ s.t. } 3 \leq x^2 \leq 7 \right\},$
\item
  $\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \left[2+\frac1{n}, 6-\frac2{n}\right],$
\item
  $\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \left[\frac1{n},n\right].$
\end{enumerate}
sols:
\textbf{Solution to 1.}

The supremum of this set is 5, since it is clearly larger than any
number in (-1,5) and no number smaller than 5 could have that property.
(If you're not convinced of this, imagine any number smaller than 5, and
call it \emph{N} then there must exist a number between \emph{N} and 5
so that \emph{N} cannot be the supremum).

And for a similar reason, the infimum of this set has to be -1.

\textbf{Solution to 2.}

Here the set that we are looking at is all the rational numbers that are
between the square root of 3 and the square root of 7. The supremum and
infimum of a set do not have to be members of the set, so our intuition
isn't bad: the supremum has to be the square root of 7 and the infimum
the square root of 3.

\textbf{Solution to 3.}

This set is the intersection of closed intervals that grow. At $n=1$ it
is the set {[}3,4{]} and then {[}2.5, 5{]}, so we have

\[\displaystyle
[3,4]Â \cap [2.5,5] \capÂ [2+\frac{1}{3},6-\frac{2}{3}] \cap [2+\frac{1}{4}, 6-\frac{2}{4}] \cap \ldots = [3,4]\]

since because we're taking an intersection of larger and larger
interval, only the smaller remains. It is now clear that the supremum of
that set is 4 and the infimum 3.

\textbf{Solution to 4.}

Here the sets also are growing in size, but this time we are taking a
union. Since 1/\emph{n} converges to 0, the left side of the interval
converges to 0 and clearly the right side of the interval converges to
infinity. This means that

\[\displaystyle
\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [\frac{1}{n},n] = (0,\infty)\]

And so the infimum of this set is 0, while there isn't a supremum since
the set does not have an upper bound.
hints:
The \emph{supremum} of a set of real numbers is the smallest real number
that is larger or equal than any number of the set. Conversely, the
\emph{infimum} of a set is the largest real number that is smaller or
equal than any number of the set.
